PIONEER Experiences

A word of explanation to the person answering this questionnaire.

It is difficult to prepare a general questionnaire on pioneer life because no individual who is asked to answer it has exactly the same experiences as another. Some of the questions here will not apply to your experiences; others may prove impossible for you to answer, so don't worry about leaving blank spaces.

Take extra thought of what you have to say, and if there is not sufficient space to answer the question, don't hesitate to give details, or describe particular events. If they help to answer the questions.

This questionnaire is intended for persons who lived in Western Canada before 1914, and may be answered by anyone who has personal experience of the pioneer years whether born in this province or not.

If more than one member of the family can answer the questions, they should write them on separate sheets or apply for a separate questionnaire.

Other Questionnaires

Saskatchewan Archives questionnaires which have been prepared or projected are listed below. Please select the ones you would be willing to answer.

- All questionnaires
- Pioneer schools
- Pioneer churches
- Pioneer recreation and social life
- Pioneer farming experiences
- Pioneers in Saskatchewan
- Pioneer health and housing

Preservation of Questionnaires

All questionnaires will be preserved in the Office of the Saskatchewan Archives at the University of Saskatchewan as part of the permanent record of our Province. Please send your completed questionnaires to:

Saskatchewan Archives Office,
University of Saskatchewan,
Saskatoon, Saskatchewan.
PIONEER EXPERIENCES

A word of caution to the pioneer

It is difficult to prepare a general questionnaire on pioneer life because no individual is asked to answer all questions. Some of the questions may be answered by others who have personal experiences of the pioneer years whether born in this province or not.

This questionnaire is intended for persons who lived in Western Canada for more than one year whether they have personal experiences of the pioneer years or not.

If more than one member of the family can answer the questions, they should write them on separate sheets or apply for separate questionnaires.

SASKATCHEWAN ARRIVALS QUESTIONNAIRE

No. 2

FARMERS' EXPERIENCES: A GENERAL QUESTIONNAIRE

PLEASE PRINT ALL PROPER NAMES AND PLACE NAMES IN CAPITAL LETTERS. IF YOU ARE NOT SURE THAT NAME IS CORRECT AS YOU HAVE GIVEN IT, PLEASE SAY SO.

1. Your full name: John Thomas Gordon
2. Your address: 607 Gladstone Road, Saskatoon, Sask.
3. Date: April 1, 1945
4. Where were you born? (Give names of places and countries)
   Ballyfermot, Dublin, Ireland
5. What was your father's name and occupation?
   Alexander Gordon, farmer
6. When did you come to Saskatchewan? (Give month and year)
   Jan. 1, 1946
7. Mention any other places where you lived before coming to Saskatchewan, giving dates wherever possible.
   Belfast, Ireland (pre-1897), 1905
8. How old were you when you first came to Western Canada? (You do not need to answer this question if you would rather not or you may use "I" was a small child," etc.)
   I was in my teens, 28 years
9. What were your reasons for coming West?
   (a) adventure, (b) to work, school
10. How did you learn about the West? (Through other people? Reading about it? Railroads or government information?)
    A booklet from Western Canada called "Beyond the Prairies" in 1944. I was delighted with the picture he gave, and immediately came.

They thought I was acting very foolishly or going off to a big city school.

By myself

13. What means of transportation did you use?
Steamer to Canada, and CPR to Regina

14. What incidents of the journey West do you remember? (People you met on the way, meetings with Indians, adventures on the journey, accidents or other excitement, etc.)
The fine sea trip to Montana! We slid slowly
Colonial ears were not immune and uncomfortable
able, a dirty team got stuck outside Ute
Regina Station, right on the street

15. Where did you first stay when you arrived in Saskatchewan?
Got a rural school as principal until I finished
+ went directly to Ute

16. Where did you settle or take up land?
Junctioned and a farmer named J. P. Smith

17. Mention any other places where you have lived since coming to Saskatchewan.
I spent almost +9 years right at Almonta

18. How did you earn a living before coming to Western Canada? How, after you came?
School teacher before I came, simply alone
For two years after I came
11. What did your friends and relatives think of your decision to come to Western Canada?
   They thought I was acting very foolishly in quitting a big city school.

    By myself

13. What means of transportation did you use?
    Steamship to Canada, and CPR to Regina

14. What incidents of the journey West do you remember? (People you met on the way, meetings with Indians, adventures on the journey, accidents or other excitement, etc.)
    The first six days to Montreal, the sea-sick.
    Colonial cars were very narrow and uncomfortable.
    After a day's travel got stuck outside the Regina Station, nights on the street.

15. Where did you first stay when you arrived in Saskatchewan?
    Got a small school as principal north of Regina directly to the west.

16. Where did you settle or take up land?
    I landed and took up land near Regina.

17. Mention any other places where you have lived since coming to Saskatchewan.
    I spent almost four years at Edmonton.

18. How did you earn a living before coming to Western Canada? How, after you came?
    School teacher before I came, taught school for two years after I came.

41. What do you think are the most important changes in your community since you first came West?

1. The farms are almost, except pasture fields, all broken up.
2. Much better type of buildings.
3. Transportation by cars, and cultivation done by powerful machines.
4. More shade trees around the farm home.
5. More substantial building in town.
